The report is not correct. This function allocates a single contiguous buffer of size unif_buf_size that explicitly includes params->opaque.value.len + 1 and params->realm.value.len + 1 when those fields exist, and unif_buf_used tracks how much of that buffer has been consumed. The call to get_rq_uname is passed the remaining buffer size (unif_buf_size - unif_buf_used), so it is constrained to the available space; its return value is added to unif_buf_used. The subsequent assignments set info->opaque and info->realm to pointers inside that pre-sized buffer and then call helpers that copy the quoted parameters into those locations. Therefore, as written the code ensures the destination buffer was sized to hold the copied strings and zero terminators, so there is no direct violation of MISRA C:2023 Rule 21.17 in this snippet.

That said, the argument made by agent A is a plausible concern only if one of the helper routines (e.g. get_rq_uname) misbehaves and returns a value larger than the remaining buffer it was given, or if the copy helpers copy more bytes than the lengths accounted for. Such a bug would be a defect in those helpers, not a direct rule breach in this function. To make the intent and safety clearer and to satisfy aggressive static-analysis checks, you could add an explicit runtime check of remaining space before each copy (or pass the remaining size into the copy helper), but that is a defensive improvement rather than proof that the current code violates Rule 21.17.
